qas.question: How has United Kingdom been governed?
Instead of the UK adopting the federalist model, what did they do?

answers.text: UK has relied on gradual devolution to decentralise political power

qas.question: When did devolution in the UK begin?

answers.text: which granted home rule to Ireland as a constituent country of the former United Kingdom of Great Britain and Ireland
eventually evolved into the modern day Republic of Ireland

qas.question: How has United Kingdom not been governed?

plausible_answers.text: UK has relied on gradual devolution to decentralise political power

qas.question: Instead of the UK adopting the federalist model, what didn't they do?
When did revolution in the UK begin?

plausible_answers.text: which granted home rule to Ireland as a constituent country of the former United Kingdom of Great Britain and Ireland
which eventually evolved into the modern day Republic of Ireland

context: The United Kingdom has traditionally been governed as a <a0_0><b5_0>unitary state<b5_0/><a0_0/> by the Westminster Parliament in London. Instead of adopting a federal model, the <a1_0><b6_0>UK has relied on gradual devolution to decentralise political power<b6_0/><a1_0/>. Devolution in the UK began with the Government of Ireland Act <a2_0><b7_0>1914<b7_0/><a2_0/> <a3_0><b8_0>which granted home rule to Ireland as a constituent country of the former United Kingdom of Great Britain and Ireland<b8_0/><a3_0/>. Following the partition of Ireland in 1921 which saw the creation of the sovereign Irish Free State (<b9_0>which <a4_0>eventually evolved into the modern day Republic of Ireland<b9_0/><a4_0/>), Northern Ireland retained its devolved government through the Parliament of Northern Ireland, the only part of the UK to have such a body at this time. This body was suspended in 1972 and Northern Ireland was governed by direct rule during the period of conflict known as The Troubles.
